title: The Residence of Sri Nityananda Prabhu | Sri Jai Chaitanya Dasa | Sri Gaura Mandala Parikrama 2024
speaker: HG Jai Chaitanya Dasa

segments.key_quote: residents of lord nithyananda prabhu at kardaha we saw a house
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the topic of Lord Nityananda Prabhu's residence in Kardaha.
segments.transcript: Residents of Lord Nithyananda Prabhu at Kardaha, we saw a house that is Nithyananda Prabhu's house, and some details about him and his house are here.

segments.key_quote: shri nithyananda prabhu is none other than lord balram the first expansion of the supreme
segments.summary: The speaker explains that Nityananda Prabhu is an incarnation of Lord Balarama and Sri Chaitanya is an incarnation of Lord Krishna.
segments.transcript: Shri Nithyananda Prabhu is none other than Lord Balaram, the first expansion of the Supreme Personality of God. Naratham Das Thakur sings, vrajendra nandana say sachi sutta haila say balram haila nithai. Vrajendra nandana is Lord Krishna, the master of Vraja, and sachi sutta refers to the son of Mother Sachi. So the same person who previously had been the darling of Vrindavana has now incarnated as Sri Chaitanya, the son of Sachi Mata. Similarly, the person who previously had been Lord Balaram has now appeared as Nithyananda Prabhu.

segments.key_quote: lord chaitanya had entrusted the preaching of bengal under the leadership of merciful nithai
segments.summary: The speaker describes how Nityananda Prabhu was ordered by Lord Chaitanya to marry and preach in Bengal.
segments.transcript: On the orders of Lord Chaitanya, Nithyananda Prabhu had returned to Bengal. He was inspired by the Lord, Nithyananda Prabhu, and instructed to get married and accept grihastha ashram. Lord Chaitanya had entrusted the preaching of Bengal under the leadership of merciful Nithai. In order to fulfill the orders of the Lord, he soon got married to the two daughters of Suryadasa Sarkhel, namely Vasudha and Janava, and settled down at Kunjavatika in the town of Kardaha.

segments.key_quote: Shri Bhirachandraprabhu was none other than Shirodakshayi Vishnu, who manifests as the super soul in all of our hearts
segments.summary: The speaker explains the identities of Nityananda Prabhu's family members as incarnations of other deities.
segments.transcript: In the course of time, He begot one son and one daughter here, Shri Bhirachandraprabhu and Srimati Ganga Devi. Shri Gaurav Ganesha Deepika reveals that Srimati Vasudha and Janava were actually the incarnations of the eternal concerts of Lord Balaram, namely Srimati Varuni and Revati Devi respectively. Shri Bhirachandraprabhu was none other than Shirodakshayi Vishnu, who manifests as the Supersoul in all of our hearts, while Mother Ganges descended as Ganga Devi, the daughter of Lord Nithyananda.

segments.key_quote: A huge mass of land suddenly appeared from the water
segments.summary: The speaker narrates the story of how Nityananda Prabhu acquired land in Kardaha through a miracle after being rebuked by a local Zamindar.
segments.transcript: So we saw the house where they were all staying after lunch this afternoon. According to hearsay, after his marriage, Lord Nithyananda had requested the local Zavindar here in Kardaha to kindly allot him a piece of land where he and his family could reside. The Zavindar, being unaware of Lord Nithyananda's divinity, rebuked him for abandoning his sanyasa and accepting a wife later on. The Zavindar, at the time of conversation, was fishing along with his friends. He sarcastically replied to Nithyananda that if he really needed a piece of land to stay, then he would have to create it out of water. Saying this, the zamindar threw a piece of burning straw into the Ganges in order to mark the place on water where the zamindar decided Lord Nithyananda should set up his residence, making fun of Lord Nithyananda Prabhu in front of his friends. Nithyananda Prabhu, who always remained very humble and without any anger, did not mind the zamindar's harsh words and assured the zamindar that whatever he had wished, though sarcastically, would surely come to pass. What happened next stunned all present. A huge mass of land suddenly appeared from the water exactly at the place where the burning piece of straw had hit it. Then this newly created island then got connected with the mainland. This place subsequently came to be known as Kardaha. Kar means straw in Bengali.

segments.key_quote: All the previous seven sons of Nithyananda Prabhu had died because Sri Abhirama Thakur had paid them his dhandavats.
segments.summary: The speaker describes Kunjavatika and the story of Abhirama Thakur's powerful blessings and Nityananda Prabhu's fear for his son Bhirachandra.
segments.transcript: His transcendental house is presently renovated all over the three worlds as Kunjavatika. There is a very sweet pastime that has been narrated in Abhirama Leelamrita which talks of Shri Abhirama Gopala Thakura's arrival in Kardaha. Shri Abhirama Gopal Thakur, one of the most prominent of the twelve cowherd boys, Dwaadasha Gopala, had a very powerful personality. He was a great friend of an intimate associate of Shri Nithyananda Prabhu. If Abhirama Thakur bowed down to any person who was not the Lord or empowered by the Lord, then that person would die immediately. Similarly, if he bowed down before any stone that was not a Saligramshila, then that stone would immediately crack. Several deities in Bengal had cracked just because Shri Abhirama had paid them his obeisances. All the previous seven sons of Nithyananda Prabhu had died because Sri Abhirama Thakur had paid them his dhandavats. However, when Sri Bhirachand Prabhu appeared in this world, Lord Nithya was very careful not to invite Sri Abhirama Gopal Thakur to attend his childbirth ceremony. He feared that Abhirama would again bow down and cause harm to the child. Though Lord Nithya was an expansion of the Supreme Lord, yet he played his part like a normal father and therefore expressed his concern and anguish. Nithyananda

segments.key_quote: But Abhirama then simply spread his grace and said, And then, sitting on that floating cloth, peacefully crossed over the river.
segments.summary: The speaker continues the story of Abhirama Thakur, describing his miraculous crossing of the Ganges and his eventual blessing of Bhirachandra.
segments.transcript: Hence, he instructed all the boatsmen of Kardaha not to transport Abhirama Thakur to the other side of Ganges in case he was seen that day. Sri Abhirama Gopal was a covert boy of Vrindavan and he neither had any ego, nor did he care for any false prestige. In a very innocent mood, living behind all inhibitions, he set out for Kardaha without any invitation to meet his dear friend and bless his newborn. When Abhirama Thakur arrived on the bank of Ganges and asked the boatmen to carry him to Kardaha, the boatmen panicked. Running out of options, they drowned their boats in the water. But Abhirama then simply spread his grace and said, and then, sitting on that floating cloth, peacefully crossed over the river. Seeing his prowess, all the onlookers were amazed. When Abhirama finally arrived at Kunjavatika, Nithyananda Prabhu courteously embraced him and fed him sumptuously. Thereafter, in spite of Srimati Janava and Vasudha Devi's presence, Abhirama bowed down again and paid his obeisances to little Birchandra. When he saw that no harm was caused to the little child, he was overjoyed and composed verses glorifying him, understanding that he was the expansion of the Supreme Lord.

segments.key_quote: Lord Nithya was almost completely devoid of any external consciousness and remained intoxicated in an ecstatic love of God.
segments.summary: The speaker concludes by glorifying Nityananda Prabhu's magnanimity, ecstatic love, and the pastimes performed in Kardaha.
segments.transcript: In an innocent mood, he sang and danced in ecstasy. Thus, Sri Birchandra Prabhu had displayed the exalted symptoms of divinity since his very birth. Sri Nithyananda Prabhu had performed the most amazing pastimes here in Kardaha, which cannot be completely described even with a thousand mouths. Such was his magnanimity, such was his mood, that he freely distributed the treasure of Lord's love. His uncommon, unique pastime moved even the atheist to cry tears of love. Lord Nithya was almost completely devoid of any external consciousness and remained intoxicated in an ecstatic love of God. In such a state of utter ecstasy, he would sometimes jump high up in the air or at other times roll over the ground while continuously glorifying the Supreme Lord. Sometimes he would laugh and at other times streams of tears would roll down his beautiful eyes. Srimati Janava Devi, Vasudha Devi, and Birchandra Prabhu have all manifested their sweet pastimes.
